questions.question_text: Which two configuration steps must be performed when managing iOS devices? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: This is kind of a poorly worded question. I can see what they are implying here (that, at a minimum, you need an AppleID in order to register an APNS token),. so I understand,. but the wording of the question is a bit tricky and misleading.

BC- 
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Workspace-ONE-UEM/2102/UEM_Installation/GUID-AWT-NEXTSTEPSKEY.html?hWord=N4IghgNiBcIIIAcEQKYAICSAREBfIA
-You may also need to create a corporate Apple ID.
-If your deployment includes Apple iOS devices, you must generate an APNs certificate on behalf of your company.
A - need to have vSphere to deploy

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a prerequisite to deploy VMware Unified Access Gateway OVF?
Which two steps would an administrator complete to enable auto-discovery for their Workspace ONE UEM environment? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Enter the email domain when establishing directory services.
choices.B: Verify the domain by accepting the link in the email that registered auto-discovery.
choices.E: Email auto-discovery@workspaceone.com with the domain the administrator wants to register.
choices.C: Register email domain within Workspace ONE UEM.
choices.A: Enter the email domain when installing the AirWatch Cloud Connector.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the device operating system on the left into the box associated with its third party messaging solution.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
iOS - APNS (Apple Push Notification service)
Android - FCM (Firebase Cloud Messaging)
Windwos - WNS (Windows Push Notification Services)

questions.question_text: Which three can be used to enforce conditional access in Workspace ONE? (Choose three.)

comments.content:
According to the above link it is CDEF 
1. Who is the user? Contractor, executive, team manager, IT staff etc. 
2. Where are they connecting from? Inside the corporate network or from home? 
3. What device are they coming from? What OS, is it managed, unmanaged, etc.? 
4. What app are they trying to access? Internal, external, high security, etc.?

CDE is correct.
"13-36 Conditional Access
With Workspace ONE Access, you can enforce conditional access based on the network range, platform, and application-specific authentication criteria. "

discussion.content: Is CDE, https://blogs.vmware.com/euc/2021/01/vmware-workspace-one-delivers-improved-multi-factor-authentication.html#:~:text=%20Workspace%20ONE%20can%20make%20conditional%20access%20decisions,access%3F%20Internal%2C%20external%2C%20high%20security%2C%20etc.%3F%20More%20 And page 562 of manual WS1

Selected Answer: CDE
This question refers specifically to the options for conditional access in Workspace ONE Access in that case the correct answer is CDE

Selected Answer: CDE
2-39 Conditional Access
With Workspace ONE Access, you can enforce conditional access based on the network range, platform, and application-specific authentication criteria.

Selected Answer: CDE
As per vmware explanation

CEF Correct answer 
C. device platform - device type 
E. network range - network range
F. user-based role - user group
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h5XIu5K6Pes&t=71s
The authentication policy you create determines which authentication method Workspace ONE Access implements, based on the network range, device type, and user group.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Workspace-ONE/services/WS1-Access-deploymentguide/GUID-61066072-5A9D-4CDE-A58F-291FEF79C202.html
The authentication policy you create determines which authentication method Workspace ONE Access implements, based on the network range, device type, and user group.

comments.content: Actually, I retract. I just noticed it says user based role. You cannot assign policies based on user role. User group, yes.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CEF
In Conditional access policies, you can only filter based on device type, user group, and network range. Then you apply this network policy to an application. So in my opinion, D is the odd one out (from CDEF).

comments.content: This is a tricky question, it could be CDE.
